Directions: In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Each question will present three words (I, II, and III) that can fill the blanks. Choose the option containing the word(s) that correctly fills the blanks to complete the passage.

Collective human memory is a partial and imperfect repository of our encounters with one another through time. We are not good at ______ (A), let alone acknowledging, the ways that these encounters have shaped our present societies, cultures and economies. So, how did we forget?

Globalisation theorists following the sociologist Roland Robertson use the term ‘glocalisation’ to describe how local cultures ______ (B) the products of the global market and turn them into something seemingly new. Through this process, incoming goods – technologies, ideas, symbols, artistic styles, social practices or institutions – are assimilated, becoming hybrid recreations that take on ______ (C) meanings. These recreations are then redeployed as new markers of cultural or class distinction, sedimenting borrowed cultural products in the collective consciousness to the point of ______ (D). And so the global becomes local, the foreign becomes familiar, and the other becomes us. Glocalisation is how and why we collectively forget. Such is the silent trick of every single globalisation in our history: our forgetfulness of it is the method and mark of its success.

Every generation appropriates the inheritances of global exchanges and refashions them as its own. Excavating the sediments our predecessors left in our collective consciousness is not a task that we are naturally ______ (E) to perform. It is an act of remembrance and self-understanding that can destabilise our identities because it counters the processes that endow them with authenticity.

Which of the following word(s) can fill in the blank labelled as (A) in the passage?

I. forgetting

II. recalling

III. remembering

Only II
Both I and II
Both II and III
Only III
All I, II, and III
132
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

In the question given below, three statements are given which may or may not contain and error in any part of the sentence. Identify the statements containing an error and also point out the part containing the error

1. Farhan supports the (A)/ idea because, first, (B)/ its simplicity second, (C) / it is unique. (D)

2. In itself, exercise does not (A)/ cause cancer; rather, a (B)/ sudden increase in a (C)/ exercise regimen can be a cause.(D)

3. Spanning six decades, a period that (A)/ encompasses dozens of albums, (B)/ Bob Dylan's career as a relevant musician (C)/ continues well into the 21st century. (D)

1-A 3-B
3-B 2-D
1-C 2-C
3-C 2-A
All sentences are correct.

In the question given below, three statements are given which may or may not contain and error in any part of the sentence. Identify the statements containing an error and also point out the part containing the error

1. One of the (A) / twenty girls in (B)/ the class has (C)/ finished their work.(D)

2. Rights activists have warned (A)/ the provision of chemical castration (B)/ could affect Pakistan’s international (C)/ human rights obligations.(D)

3. Candy Chang is an artist, designer, and urban planner.(A)/ She looks at how we can make cities more comfortable (B)/ and thoughtful places, where we can (C)/ better understand and know our neighbors. (D)

1-C 3-A
2-A 3-D
1-A 2-A
3-D 2-B
Any other combination

Direction: In the question below, there are two statements. Each statement consists of two blanks. You have to choose the option which provides the correct set of words that fit both the blanks in both the statements appropriately and in the same order making them meaningful and grammatically correct.

Mr. Modi was whole-heartedly in favour of the _____ , and frequently _____ his party friends to remain true to it.

As a single person, I find it very difficult to fight the _____ of my neighbors who are against the installation of a neighborhood charter, so I solemnly _____the higher authorities to stand in my support.

affiliation, declined
combination, appealed
coalition, adjured
​union, trespassed
alliance, impoverished

A. The Narcotics Control Bureau is the Indian central law enforcement and intelligence agency.
B. The agency is tasked with combating drug trafficking and the use of illegal substances.
C. Established in 1986, it is responsible for coordination with the Indian state governments and other central departments.
D. It is the domestic intelligence and security service of the United States and its principal federal law enforcement agency.
E. The NCB is outside the ambit of the Right to Information Act under Section 24(1) of the RTI act 2005.

A
B
C
D
E

B. Wole Soyinka is a Nigerian playwright, novelist, poet, and essayist in the English language.
C. He was awarded the 1986 Nobel Prize in Literature, the first sub-Saharan African to be honored in that category.
D. In 1954, he attended Government College in Ibadan, and subsequently University College Ibadan and the University of Leeds in England.
E. After studying in Nigeria and the UK, he worked with the Royal Court Theatre in London.

D. By abolishing this article, the government can act tough against the terrorism present in the region.

Directions: Choose the combination that creates a grammatically and contextually coherent sentence.

A. The legislation was passed unanimously,

i. even if

D. the bill had been a topic of contention for months.

B. He spoke eloquently on the matter,

ii. notwithstanding

E. he was aware that not everyone agreed with his viewpoint.

C. The project was successfully completed on schedule,

iii. although

F. there were numerous obstacles along the way.
A-i-E
C-iii-F and A-iii-D
B-ii-D
A-iii-D and B-ii-D
B-i-F

F. ensuring that the products met the highest standards.

F. the students would benefit from additional practice.

Below, a set of eight statements is given, out of which the first sentence, given in bold, is fixed. The rest are jumbled in any random order. Out of the remaining seven statements, one does not belong to the passage. Rearrange the remaining sentences in the correct order and then answer the questions.

A. Visual anthropology is an academic subfield of anthropology that has two distinct but intersecting aims.

B. Visual anthropology methods include photo-elicitation, the use of images to stimulate culturally relevant reflections from informants.

C. How significant is the visual aspect of life in any particular society or civilization? etc.

D. The end results of these methods are narratives (film, video, photo essays) which communicate typical events of a cultural scene.

E. These include How far do humans as a species rely on what is seen, and how do they integrate that into their lives?

F. The first involves the addition of images to ethnographic studies, to enhance the communication of anthropological observations through the use of photography, film, and video.

G. The second one is more or less the anthropology of art, understanding visual images to address certain questions.

H. Visual scholars must understand that it is unethical to alter images to change their meaning or present an image that connotes a reality not consistent with the understood reality.

Which of the following sentences is SECOND in the correct order?

E
G
B
C
F

154
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Below, a set of eight statements is given, out of which the first sentence, given in bold, is fixed. The rest are jumbled in any random order. Out of the remaining seven statements, one does not belong to the passage. Rearrange the remaining sentences in the correct order and then answer the questions.

A. Visual anthropology is an academic subfield of anthropology that has two distinct but intersecting aims.

B. Visual anthropology methods include photo-elicitation, the use of images to stimulate culturally relevant reflections from informants.

C. How significant is the visual aspect of life in any particular society or civilization? etc.

D. The end results of these methods are narratives (film, video, photo essays) which communicate typical events of a cultural scene.

E. These include How far do humans as a species rely on what is seen, and how do they integrate that into their lives?

F. The first involves the addition of images to ethnographic studies, to enhance the communication of anthropological observations through the use of photography, film, and video.

G. The second one is more or less the anthropology of art, understanding visual images to address certain questions.

H. Visual scholars must understand that it is unethical to alter images to change their meaning or present an image that connotes a reality not consistent with the understood reality.

Which of the following sentences is SIXTH in the correct order?
D
G
B
C
E
155
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Which of the following best explains why being "average" is perceived as failure in modern societies, according to the passage
The prevalence of rigid societal norms that discourage individuality.
The growing emphasis on personal uniqueness and competitive standards of success.
The inability of individuals to adapt to rapid technological and social advancements.
The decline of traditional industries that once provided stable roles in society.
The lack of access to basic necessities like housing and healthcare.
156
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

In the following sentence, a blank is given. Choose the phrase that best fits in the blank to complete the meaning of the sentence.

“Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem ____.”

that promotes economic inequality.
dynamics observed in modern capitalist societies.
system that provides a sense of superiority.
driven by the dissolution of gender roles.
competition inherent in feudal societies.
157
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

In the following question, a word 'misinformation' has been highlighted from the passage. Choose the option that represents the word most opposite in meaning to the highlighted word.
Clarity
Truth
Verification
Certainty
Disinformation

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Based on the correct meaning and usage of the underlined word 'inconceivable' in the passage, pick and choose the one that deems fit to be used both grammatically and meaningfully.
It is inconceivable to imagine a world without modern technology, as it plays a crucial role in our daily lives.
The inconceivable food at the restaurant left everyone satisfied and praising the chef.
Her inconceivable smile lit up the room, spreading warmth and joy among everyone
For the team to win the tournament without proper preparation was deemed inconceivable by all experts.
The inconceivable weather today has made it perfect for a picnic with family and friends.

English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Which of the following is a suitable title for the passage?
The Decline of Feudal Hierarchies and Modern Society
The Global Crisis of Self-Esteem in a Competitive World
Masculinity and Its Role in Social Inequalities
The Tyranny of Success and Social Mobility
The Role of Luck in Modern Achievements

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

What does the author suggest about luck in relation to success?
Luck plays no role in achieving success.
Reflecting on luck can reduce the competitive pressure for self-esteem.
Luck primarily benefits individuals in feudal societies.
Luck undermines societal efforts to create equality.
Luck is the sole reason for peoples’ success in today’s day and age.

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Which of the following best describes the "crisis of masculinity" mentioned in the passage
A response to evolving gender norms and societal structures.
A decline in economic opportunities for women.
An inherent result of income inequality in modern societies.
A problem exclusive to post-industrial communities.
More than one of the above.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.

Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Which of the following statements is TRUE according to the passage?
Feudal societies had fluid social positions, promoting competition for self-esteem.
The self-esteem crisis stems from the dissolution of rigid social roles and increased emphasis on individuality.
In modern societies, poverty is rarely equated with personal failure.
Social mobility is thriving in the current capitalist system.
More than one of the above.

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

What is the primary reason for the self-esteem crisis in modern societies, as described in the passage?
Decline of social mobility and rising income inequalities.
Strict adherence to feudal hierarchies.
Lack of access to education and healthcare.
Gender-specific issues in masculinity.
None of the above.
164
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Read the passage given below and then answer the questions given below the passage.

In today's world, there is a pervasive belief that talent or effort can elevate anyone to the top, but this myth can be particularly harmful. The early 21st century is marked by various crises—liberal democracy, the global economy, the environment, ageing populations, migration, misinformation, and masculinity—all collectively described as a global "polycrisis." Adding to this, there exists a subtler but equally serious issue: a global crisis in self-esteem.
 Self-esteem, or one’s evaluation of personal success based on individual standards, is in decline worldwide. In globalized and economically unequal societies, this issue is most acute. Modern self-esteem is tied to individual performance, unlike the rigid social roles of feudal societies where expectations were limited to one’s predetermined position. In premodern times, success was relative to one’s role, providing a sense of normalcy. However, as feudal hierarchies dissolved and the doctrines of universal rights gained prominence, self-worth became linked to personal achievements and individuality.
Today, societal narratives emphasize "being true to oneself" and pursuing unique paths, which has led to intense competition for self-esteem. Even ordinary decisions, such as choosing a career, are seen as expressions of individuality. While this ethos allows for diversity, it fosters an environment where success is defined by outperformance. For many, this makes being "average" feel like failure, creating feelings of inadequacy and guilt.
The fluidity of modern social positions contributes to this crisis. Unlike in feudal societies, where social mobility was inconceivable, today’s aspirational narratives make it imaginable for anyone to become a billionaire or a celebrity. Although actual social mobility has declined, the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations. This mindset equates normality or poverty with personal failure, intensifying feelings of shame. Furthermore, the stark income inequalities of modern capitalism exacerbate these issues, as comparisons to those more successful highlight one’s perceived inferiority.
The self-esteem crisis sheds light on other societal issues, such as the so-called masculinity crisis. Men often feel like failures, not simply due to evolving gender norms but because societal structures make nearly everyone feel inferior. Male frustration, disengagement, and anger stem from the same competitive self-esteem _______. Similarly, in post-industrial communities, the loss of industries represents more than just economic decline—it erases social roles that once provided individuals with a sense of purpose and success. 
Solving the self-esteem crisis requires broadening access to self-worth. Stable employment, decent housing, and healthcare are foundational, but societal standards of success also need redefining. Political philosophers like Michael Walzer and Timo Jütten argue for expanding "standards of contribution," recognizing diverse forms of achievement such as caregiving, art, activism, and community engagement. Reforming education systems to instill these values is crucial. Additionally, acknowledging the role of luck in success, as argued by Michael Sandel in The Tyranny of Merit (2020), can mitigate the relentless competition for self-esteem. By shifting our focus from individualistic competition to collective recognition of diverse contributions, society can alleviate the self-esteem crisis. Emphasizing shared humanity and celebrating varied achievements may help rebuild a sense of purpose and worth in an increasingly unequal world.

Which of the following is NOT correct according to the passage?
Self-esteem in modern societies is tied to individual performance rather than rigid social roles.
Modern social mobility has declined, but the possibility of success creates unrealistic expectations.
Feudal societies lacked social mobility, and success was relative to one’s role.
The self-esteem crisis only affects men, as mentioned in the passage.
None of the above.
165
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options:

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

According to the passage, in which year did Das withdraw from parliamentary politics?
1975
1957
1967
1942
1951
166
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

According to the passage, Pushpalata Das was the secretary of which organization during her school days? 
Mukti Sangha
Congress Planning Committee
Assam Legislative Assembly
Mrityu Bahini
Women Sub Committee

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options:

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

What will fit in the blank taken from the passage:
She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934.
across
for
as
to
of

English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options:

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

Which of the following is/are correct according to the given passage?
 
A. It was during the period when Pushpalata Das was a member of the Rajya Sabha that she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency.
B. She did not returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini in Mumbai.
C. Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai and stayed there for two years.
Only A
Only B
Only C
Both A and B
Both A and C

English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options:

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

Choose the Antonym of the word 'precursor'.
Harbinger
Ancestor
Pioneer
Descendant
Usher
170
English Language
+0.5s, -0.125s

Directions: Read the passage given below and answer the questions that follow by choosing the correct/most appropriate options:

Born on 27 March 1915 to Rameswar Saikia and Swarnalata in North Lakhimpur in Assam, Pushpalata Das did her schooling at Panbazar Girls High School. She started her political activities in her school days and was the secretary of an organization by the name of Mukti Sangha. In 1931, she and her comrades organized a protest against the hanging of the revolutionary, Bhagat Singh by the British Raj and were expelled from school.

She continued her studies ____ a private student and passed the matriculation examination in 1934, after which she joined Benaras Hindu University to complete her intermediate course. Later, she graduated from Andhra University and secured a post-graduate degree from the same university in 1938. Subsequently, she enrolled herself for studies in law at Earle Law College, Guwahati where continued her student politics; she was the secretary of the college union in 1940. It was during this time, Gandhiji called for Individual Satyagraha, as a part of the civil disobedience movement and as a precursor to the Quit India Movement which would be launched two years later, and Das participated in the movement. She was incarcerated which effectively cut short her law studies.

Due to her association with the National Planning Committee as a member of its Women Sub Committee, Das moved to Mumbai that year and stayed there for two years. Her activities gave her opportunities to work alongside Mridula Sarabhai and Vijaya Laxmi Pandit as well as Omeo Kumar Das, then sitting member of the Assam Legislative Assembly, whom she married in 1942. She returned to Assam after her marriage and formed two organizations, Shanti Bahini and Mrityu Bahini.

After the Indian independence in 1947, the Das couple focused their activities in Dhekiajuli in Assam which Omeo Kumar Das represented in Assam Legislative Assembly for successive terms from 1951 to 1967. Pushpalata Das herself was nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1951 and held the position in 1961. It was during this period she led the 1957 election campaign of Chandraprava Saikiani from the Bajali constituency. Later, she was elected to the Congress Working Committee in 1958 and the next year, she visited a number of East European countries as a member of the parliamentary delegation. In 1967, she contested from Dhekiajuli when her husband vacated the constituency, winning the election representing Indian National Congress and repeating the success in 1971. After the death of her husband on 23 January 1975, Das withdrew from parliamentary politics, concentrating more on social service. She served as the chairperson of the Assam chapter of the All India Khadi Board and chaired the state boards of Bhudan and Gramdan initiatives. She was also associated with the Central Social Welfare Board and served as a member of the women's section of the Congress Planning Committee and the East India wing of the Censor Board of India. She edited the Assamese magazine, Jayanti and headed the Assam branch of the Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Trust for a certain period of time. She also published one book, Rajaram Sukla rashtriyaatma varcasva evam krtitva, san 1898-1962, released in 1976.

Choose the Synonym of the word 'incarcerate'.
Liberate
Detain
Cease
Propagate
Emancipate
